text.headline: Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning
text.text:
Machine learning has evolved along two main paths: supervised learning, which learns from labeled data, and unsupervised learning, which finds patterns in unlabeled data.

Let's delve into the history of machine learning...

media.caption: An image from IBM where Arthur Samuel is testing the game.

text.headline: Samuel's Checkers Program
text.text: Arthur Samuel developed a checkers game that improved by playing against itself and learning from outcomes. This was the first application of supervised learning in games.

text.headline: Creation of Perceptron (Rosenblatt)
text.text:
Frank Rosenblatt introduced the Perceptron, described as a simple neural model that can adjust weight values on labeled data on training.

Initially, it was used for binary classification tasks which can answer yes or no.

media.caption: Example of K means on a graph

text.headline: k-Means (Lloyd)
text.text:
Along with the rising of supervised machine learning, Stuart Lloyd introduced the algorithm for quatizing signals, this was commonly know today as k-Means.

With this approach, there is no need to labels, just grouped by similar data points.

.

text.headline: Regression in Computing
text.text: Known for their use on statistics, Linear and Logistic regression became standard computational tools for supervised prediction. These methods were evolved from being used for pure statistics into machine learning.

media.caption: Visualization of what a hopfield network looks like.

text.headline: Hopfield Networks
text.text: Invented by Dr. John Hopfield, Hopfield Network is a fully interconnected neural network where each unit is connected to every other unit. It behaves in a discrete manner.

media.caption: Visualization of Backpropagation in Neural Networks.

text.headline: Backpropagation
text.text:
Reintroduced by Rumelhart, Hinton, and Williams. BackPropagation is a core algorithm in machine learning, particularly for training artificial neural networks.

It's goal is to reduce the difference between the model's predicted output and the actual output by adjusting the weights and biases in the network..

media.caption: Visualization of Self-Organizing Maps for Artificial Intelligence.

text.headline: Self-Organizing Maps (Kohonen)
text.text: Also known as Kohonen Maps, are a type of artificial neural network that uses unsupervised learning to cluster high-dimensional data into a lower-dimensional representation. This was pivotal in visualization and exploratory data analysis without labels..

text.headline: Support Vector Machines (SVMs)
text.text: Is a supervised machine learning algoritm used for classification and regression tasks. It tries to find the best boundary known as hyperplane that separates different classes in the data.

text.headline: The End!
text.text:
Thank You for reading my slides about the history of Maachine Learning.

BYEEEEE!!!
